questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive patient presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and a rapid heartbeat. His blood pressure is 180/120mmHg. To manage his condition, a Phentolamine is administered. Later, he experiences an allergic reaction, and epinephrine is given to treat this condition. Which of the following best describes the Vasomotor reversal of Dale?

choices.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased blood pressure.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased heart rate.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decrease in heart rate.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.

Explanation:

  • Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha-adrenergic blocker that blocks alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors, causing vasodilation and decreased peripheral resistance.

  • When epinephrine (which acts on both alpha and beta receptors) is administered after phentolamine blockade, alpha receptors are blocked, so epinephrine‚Äôs alpha-mediated vasoconstriction is blocked.

  • Therefore, epinephrine‚Äôs beta-2 mediated vasodilation predominates, causing vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure (paradoxical hypotension).

  • This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale or the "epinephrine reversal" phenomenon.

  • The heart rate usually increases due to beta-1 stimulation by epinephrine and reflex tachycardia secondary to decreased blood pressure.

  • Vasomotor reversal of Dale (Epinephrine reversal)

Aspect Details
Definition Paradoxical decrease in blood pressure when epinephrine is administered after alpha-blockade
Mechanism Alpha blockade by drugs like phentolamine blocks vasoconstrictive alpha-1 receptors; epinephrine‚Äôs beta-2 vasodilation dominates
Clinical significance Important to recognize during treatment involving alpha blockers and catecholamines
Effect on blood pressure Decrease due to unopposed beta-2 vasodilation
Effect on heart rate Increased due to beta-1 stimulation and reflex tachycardia
Historical note Described by Dale, illustrating receptor interplay in vascular tone regulation

¬†

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased blood pressure (Option A): Incorrect because alpha receptors are blocked, so vasoconstriction is prevented and BP decreases.

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased heart rate (Option C): Incorrect as a description of vasomotor reversal; HR does increase but the key feature is BP decrease.

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decrease in heart rate (Option D): Incorrect because heart rate increases due to beta-1 stimulation and reflex tachycardia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with poorly controlled hypertension despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. The physician initiates Clonidine therapy to help manage the patient's blood pressure. Which of the following is TRUE regarding the mechanism of action of Clonidine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Stimulates Œ±2-adrenergic receptors.

Explanation:

¬†

Clonidine reduces sympathetic outflow from the CNS by agonising Œ±2-adrenergic receptors.

¬†

Mechanism of action

Uses
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetic diarrhoea
  • Addiction withdrawal
  • Menopausal hot flashes
  • Diagnosing hypertension
  • Suspected pheochromocytoma
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • ADHD
  • Tourette syndrome
  • Hyperhidrosis

¬†

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for managing a hypertensive crisis caused by the sudden withdrawal of Clonidine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phentolamine

Explanation:

¬†

  • Clonidine is commonly used to manage hypertension
  • Sudden discontinuation of clonidine can lead to a withdrawal syndrome characterized by various symptoms, including headache, apprehension, tremors, abdominal pain, sweating, and tachycardia
  • This syndrome typically occurs 18 to 36 hours after stopping the medication and is associated with increased sympathetic discharge, as evidenced by elevated plasma and urine concentrations of catecholamines and metabolites
  • In the management of a hypertensive crisis, promptly resume Clonidine administration, and Phentolamine is considered the drug of choice for a hypertensive crisis
  • Common side effects include dry eyes and mouth due to its antimuscarinic properties, sedation, hypotension, and erectile dysfunction

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with chronic hypertension presents to her obstetrician's office for a routine prenatal visit. She has been managed with methyldopa for hypertension control. Which adverse effect should the physician monitor for during her treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Hemolytic anemia

Explanation:

¬†

  • Methyldopa, a centrally acting sympatholytic agent, is utilized in hypertension management, particularly during pregnancy and in patients with renal insufficiency
  • Damage to red blood cells (Warm Antibody Hemolytic Anemia) occurs when alpha-methyldopa attaches to the RBC surface, rendering the RBC antigenic
  • This attachment triggers the production of antibodies (IgG), which target and destroy the RBCs and is classified as a Type II Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Regular monitoring, including Coombs' test for hemolytic anemia and liver function tests, is imperative for the early detection of adverse events

¬†

Category

Details

Mechanism of Action

Centrally converted to methyl norepinephrine, exerting alpha-2 agonistic action in the CNS, reducing adrenergic outflow.

Uses

Management of hypertension, particularly in pregnant women or those with renal insufficiency.

Side Effects

Nausea, Diarrhea, Headache, Dizziness, Sedation, Dry mouth, Rash. Rare complications include Coombs-positive hemolytic anaemia, lupus-like syndrome, myocarditis, pancreatitis, hepatotoxicity, and immune thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with severe episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and elevated urinary metanephrines is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. What is the drug of choice to manage hypertension and symptoms before surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Phenoxybenzamine

Explanation:

¬†

  • Phenoxybenzamine is utilized to manage paroxysmal hypertension and sweating caused by conditions like pheochromocytoma.

¬†

Class

Mechanism of Action

Side Effects

Nonselective, irreversible alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonists

Forms covalent bonds, likely with cysteine residues, within alpha-adrenergic receptors, reducing sympathetic effects induced by catecholamines. Results in decreased vasoconstriction and systemic vascular resistance.

Postural hypotension, palpitations, nasal congestion, miosis, inhibition of ejaculation.

¬†

  • Prazosin can be used as an alternative, but the drug of choice for pheochromocytoma is Phenoxybenzamine.

questions.text:
During the surgical excision of a pheochromocytoma, a continuous IV infusion of an alpha blocker was used to prevent the intraoperative rise of blood pressure due to catecholamine spillage into the bloodstream from the tumor. Match the alpha-blockers with their appropriate class.


	
		
			
			a. Phenoxybenzamine
			
			
			1. Alpha 1 selective
			
		
		
			
			b. Prazosin
			
			
			2. Alpha Non-selective and reversible
			
		
		
			
			c. Phentolamine
			
			
			3. Alpha 2 selective
			
		
		
			
			d. Yohimbine
			
			
			4. Alpha Non-selective and irreversible
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3

Explanation:

¬†

Classification of Alpha-blockers based on their receptor binding:

TYPES

DRUGS

Non-competitive + irreversible type

Phenoxybenzamine









¬†

Competitive + reversible type

 ¬†

Non-selective

Phentolamine

Ergotamine

Ergotoxine

Chlorpromazine




¬†

Alpha 1 selective

Drugs

LOCATION

EFFECTS

Alpha 1 a

Tamsulosin

Silodosin

Internal Urethral Sphincter

Iris

Ejaculation failure/retrograde ejaculation, miosis, increased urine outflow

Alpha 1 b

Alfuzosin

Doxazosin

Prazosin

Terazosin

Vascular Smooth Muscle

Vasodilatation, reflex tachycardia, reduced GFR (thus leading to RAAS activation)

Alpha 2 selective

Yohimbine

Idoxazon

Central Nervous System

Penile erection (used in depression with sexual dysfunction)

¬†

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with benign prostate hypertrophy was recently prescribed Prazosin. Which side effects should the patient be informed about before starting the medication?


	Postural hypotension
	Retrograde ejaculation
	Floppy iris syndrome
	Reflex bradycardia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

  • Postural hypotension (1):
    Due to Œ±1B receptor blockade in vascular smooth muscle ‚Üí vasodilation ‚Üí sudden drop in BP on standing (first-dose effect).
    ¬†
  • Retrograde ejaculation (2):
    Œ±1A blockade at the internal urethral sphincter ‚Üí sphincter fails to close during ejaculation ‚Üí semen flows backward into the bladder.
    ¬†
  • Floppy iris syndrome (3):
    Œ±1 receptor blockade in iris dilator muscle ‚Üí leads to poor pupil dilation and billowing of the iris during eye surgery (noted especially in patients undergoing cataract surgery).
    ¬†
  • Reflex bradycardia (4):
    Incorrect: Prazosin typically causes reflex tachycardia, not bradycardia. When vasodilation causes a fall in BP, baroreceptor reflexes increase sympathetic output ‚Üí tachycardia. Bradycardia is more common with drugs that increase vagal tone (e.g., clonidine, Œ≤-blockers).
    ¬†

Prazosin in BPH and Related Side Effects:

Aspect

Details

Drug Class

Selective Œ±1-adrenergic receptor blocker

Mechanism

Œ±1A blockade ‚Üí relaxes bladder neck/prostate smooth muscle

Œ±1B blockade ‚Üí vasodilation

Uses

BPH

Hypertension

Raynaud‚Äôs disease

Scorpion bite

Bladder/Prostate Effect

‚Üì Outlet resistance ‚Üí better urine flow

Vascular Effect

‚Üì Peripheral resistance ‚Üí ‚Üì BP

Adverse Effects

Postural hypotension

Common; occurs with first dose

Reflex tachycardia

Compensatory response to hypotension

Retrograde ejaculation

Due to relaxation of internal urethral sphincter

Floppy iris syndrome

Seen during eye surgery; risk increases with chronic use

¬†

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a recent history of myocardial infarction was started on Beta blocker as a secondary prophylaxis of MI. Which of the following beta blockers is most cardioselective?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Metoprolol

Explanation:

¬†

  • Metoprolol is a second-generation/cardioselective ùõÉ-blocker used as a secondary prophylaxis for myocardial infarction. It helps prevent reinfarction and arrhythmias.
  • It is more potent in blocking ùõÉ1-receptor (cardiac muscle) than ùõÉ2-receptor (bronchial muscles).

¬†

Classification of ùõÉ-blockers:

First generation(Older / non selective)

Second generation

(Cardioselective)

Third generation

Propranolol (Option B)

Sotalol

Pindolol (100% bioavailability)

Timolol

Nadolol (Maximum t1/2)

Metoprolol (Option A)

Esmolol (Minimum t1/2)

Atenolol

Bisoprolol

Acebutolol


¬†

With alpha-blocking activity

Labetalol (Option C)

Celiprolol

Nebivolol (NO-releasing property)

Betaxolol

With calcium channel blockade

Carvedilol (maximum plasma protein binding )

With beta 2 agonism

Bopindolol

With K+ channel opening action

Tilisolol (Option D)

¬†

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient who was on propranolol developed bradycardia and was admitted to the cardiac ICU. On discharge, her medication was changed from propranolol to another beta-blocker, which has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and membrane-stabilizing properties.Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pindolol

Explanation:

¬†

  • Pindolol is a potent, non-selective beta blocker with
    • Intrinsic sympathomimetic activity
    • Membrane stabilizing property
    • Lower risk for rebound hypertension when medication is stopped
  • As it has a sympathetic activity, it does not cause bradycardia; thus, it is safe for cardiovascular conditions
  • It also blocks sodium channels on the heart muscle‚Äôs membrane, hence exhibiting a membrane stabilizing action, and thus, it can be used in
    • Atrial fibrillation
    • Ventricular fibrillation
  • It also blocks sodium channels in neurons, leading to decreased nerve conduction.

¬†

Non selective ùõÉ1 + ùõÉ2 blocker

Cardioselective ùõÉ1 blocker

Without ISA

With ISA

With …ë blocking activity

 ¬†
  • Metoprolol (Option B)
  • Esmolol
  • Atenolol
  • Bisoprolol
  • Acebutolol
  • Betaxolol
  • Nebivolol
  • Propranolol

(Option D)

  • Sotalol
  • Timolol
  • Pindolol
  • Celiprolol
  • Oxprenolol
  • Penbutolol
  • Pindolol
  • Bopindolol
  • Labetalol
  • Carvedilol (Option A)

ISA: intrinsic sympathomimetic action

¬†

Beta-blockers with membrane stabilizing activity (MSA) are:

  • Propranolol (Maximum MSA)
  • Metoprolol
  • Sotalol
  • Labetalol
  • Acebutolol
  • Pindolol

¬†

Carvedilol (Option A):¬†It has multiple mechanisms of action, namely, ùõÉ1 + ùõÉ2 + ùù∞1 blockade and Calcium channel blocker. It is used as a cardioprotective agent in congestive cardiac failure.

Metoprolol (Option B): It is the prototype cardioselective ùõÉ1 blocker, which may be used in diabetic patients receiving oral hypoglycemia (beta blockers are usually contraindicated). It is also used in people intolerant to propranolol, which causes cold hands and feet.

Propranolol (Option D): It is a non-selective beta blocker without intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, and membrane stabilizing property is present only at high doses.

¬†

questions.text: A 63-year-old male has complained of tremors in his hands for the past two years. Physical examination reveals bilateral symmetric tremors predominantly in his hands, which worsen with intentional movements and are relieved by rest. Which of the following is the drug of choice in essential tremors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Propranolol

Explanation:

¬†

Essential tremor is seen in the hands and arms bilaterally and is symmetric. It can be elicited with the arms suspended against gravity in a fixed posture and during goal-directed activity. It is relieved by alcohol. Propranolol(beta-blocker) is the drug of choice.

Uses of beta-blockers:

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina: Decrease the frequency of attacks and increase exercise tolerance.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: Used in both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Congestive heart failure: Decreases mortality.
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Propranolol controls the sympathetic symptoms
  • Glaucoma: Timolol and Betaxolol are used.
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of hypertension on metoprolol presents for a routine follow-up. She mentions experiencing fatigue and occasional dizziness. She also notes episodes of constipation. Which of the following is NOT an adverse effect of beta blockers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Retrograde ejaculation

Explanation:

Retrograde ejaculation is a side effect of alpha-blockers

The cardiac side effects of beta blockers include

  • Beta-blocker withdrawal can lead to the precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Negative chronotropic effects include the development of sinus bradycardia and heart block.
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

¬†

The extracardiac side effects include

  • Increased airway resistance; hence, they are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • In Hypoglycemia, Beta-blockers mask the signs seen in a hypoglycemic patient, such as tachycardia.
  • Hyperkalemia¬†
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

questions.text: Which of the following calcium channel blockers can cause heart blockage when combined with beta-blockers in patients with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diltiazem

Explanation:

¬†

Diltiazem, which is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, can cause bradycardia and heart block when used in combination with beta-blockers in patients with heart failure.

  • A non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (i.e., diltiazem, verapamil) should not be simultaneously prescribed with a beta blocker since both classes have negative inotropic and chronotropic effects and can lead to bradycardia and heart block.
  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., Nifedipine, Nimodipine, and Amlodipine), when added to beta-blockers, increase heart rate and decrease blood pressure, resulting in an augmented symptom benefit compared with either drug class alone.

Feature

DHP Calcium Channel Blockers

Non-DHP Calcium Channel Blockers

Examples

Amlodipine, Nifedipine, Felodipine

Diltiazem, Verapamil

Mechanism of Action

Primarily block L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle

Block L-type calcium channels in the heart

Uses

Hypertension

Angina, rate control in arrhythmias

Side Effects

Peripheral edema, flushing, headache

Bradycardia, heart block, dizziness

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms of hypoglycemia is NOT masked by propranolol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sweating

Explanation:

Sweating, a symptom of hypoglycemia, is caused by cholinergic receptors and is not inhibited by beta blockers.

  • Prolonged propranolol therapy may impair carbohydrate tolerance in prediabetics by decreasing insulin release, leading to hyperglycemia and diabetes.
  • In diabetics, propranolol is avoided because of the risk of hypoglycemic episodes, as glycogenolysis in the heart, skeletal muscles, and liver that occurs due to sympathetic stimulation is attenuated.
  • In diabetic patients, beta blockers mask the signs of hypoglycemia mediated through sympathetic stimulation (tachycardia, tremor, palpitations) (Option A, B, C ruled out). Patients fail to recognise key symptoms of a hypoglycemic state and neglect getting appropriate treatment.
